name: Hydrogen
interesting_facts: It is the most abundant element in the universe.
90% of the atoms in the universe are hydrogen atoms.
It is the lightest element on the periodic table.

compounds.properties: Essential for all known forms of life. Polar molecule, excellent solvent.
Primary component of natural gas. A potent greenhouse gas.
Used in fertilizers and cleaning products. Colorless gas with a pungent odor.
Used as an antiseptic and bleaching agent. Decomposes into water and oxygen.
A colorless gas that forms hydrochloric acid when dissolved in water. Strong acid.

name: Helium
common_uses: Creating an inert atmosphere for welding
interesting_facts: Helium is the second most abundant element in the universe.
It was discovered in the sun before it was found on Earth.
It has the lowest boiling point of any element.

compounds.properties: Helium is a noble gas and is extremely unreactive. It does not form stable compounds under normal conditions.

name: Lithium
interesting_facts: It is the lightest metal on the periodic table.
Lithium is so reactive it is stored in oil.
It is the only alkali metal that doesn't form a compound with nitrogen at room temperature.

compounds.properties: Used in batteries and as a mood stabilizer in medicine for bipolar disorder.
A strong base used in electric vehicle batteries and to absorb carbon dioxide in submarines.

name: Beryllium
interesting_facts: It is a lightweight and strong metal.
Beryllium is a key component in the gems emeralds and aquamarines.
Inhaling beryllium dust is toxic and can cause a lung disease called berylliosis.

compounds.properties: A ceramic with high thermal conductivity, used in electronics.
Used in the production of nuclear fuels and in the synthesis of other beryllium compounds.

name: Boron
interesting_facts: It is an essential micronutrient for plants.
Boron is the only non-metal in its group on the periodic table.
Boron nitride is a compound of boron that is one of the hardest known materials.

compounds.properties: Used as an antiseptic, insecticide, flame retardant, and in the manufacture of glass and fiberglass.
A common cleaning agent, laundry booster, and ingredient in glazes and enamels.

name: Carbon
interesting_facts: It is the basis of all known life on Earth.
Carbon can form a vast number of compounds, more than any other element.
It has several allotropes, including diamond, graphite, and fullerenes.

compounds.properties: A greenhouse gas used by plants for photosynthesis and as a fire extinguisher.
The primary component of natural gas, used as a fuel and in chemical synthesis.

name: Nitrogen
interesting_facts: It is the most abundant element in Earth's atmosphere, making up about 78%.
Nitrogen is a crucial component of DNA and amino acids.
It is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas.

compounds.properties: A colorless gas used in the production of fertilizers, explosives, and cleaning products.
A strong and corrosive mineral acid used in the production of fertilizers and explosives.

name: Oxygen
interesting_facts: It is the most abundant element in Earth's crust.
Oxygen is crucial for aerobic respiration in most living organisms.
It makes up about 21% of the air we breathe.

compounds.properties: Essential for all known forms of life. A polar molecule and an excellent solvent.
A clear liquid used as a disinfectant, bleach, and oxidizing agent.

name: Fluorine
interesting_facts: It is the most reactive and electronegative of all chemical elements.
Pure fluorine is a highly toxic, pale yellow gas.
It is the only element that can react with a noble gas like Xenon.

compounds.properties: A colorless gas that forms hydrofluoric acid, used to etch glass.
An inorganic salt commonly added to toothpaste and municipal water supplies to prevent dental cavities.

name: Neon
interesting_facts: It is a noble gas, meaning it is very unreactive.
Neon produces a reddish-orange glow when an electric current passes through it.
The name 'neon' comes from the Greek word 'neos', meaning new.

compounds.properties: Neon is a noble gas and is considered chemically inert. No stable compounds have been confirmed under normal conditions.

name: Sodium
interesting_facts: It is a highly reactive alkali metal that is soft enough to be cut with a knife.
Sodium reacts violently with water, producing hydrogen gas and heat.
It is an essential element for nerve function in humans.

compounds.properties: Common table salt, essential for life and widely used in food and chemical production.
Known as baking soda, it is a common leavening agent and antacid.

name: Magnesium
common_uses: Alloys for car parts and aircraft
interesting_facts: It is the lightest structural metal on the periodic table.
Magnesium burns with a brilliant white light.
It is a key component of chlorophyll, the substance that gives plants their green color.

compounds.properties: A white hygroscopic solid used as a refractory material in ceramics and as an antacid.
Commonly known as Epsom salt, used in medicine, agriculture, and flotation tanks.

name: Aluminum
interesting_facts: It is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust.
Aluminum is highly recyclable and requires far less energy to recycle than to produce from ore.
It is naturally coated with a thin layer of protective oxide, which prevents corrosion.

compounds.properties: Found in nature as the minerals corundum (ruby and sapphire) and used in ceramics and abrasives.
A powerful Lewis acid used as a catalyst in many industrial chemical reactions.

name: Silicon
interesting_facts: It is the second most abundant element in Earth's crust.
Silicon is a semiconductor, which is vital for the entire electronics industry.
It is the main component of sand and quartz.

compounds.properties: The main component of sand, glass, and quartz. Used in ceramics and as an abrasive.
An extremely hard and strong material used in abrasives, car brakes, and high-temperature semiconductors.

name: Phosphorus
appearance: colorless, waxy white, yellowish or red-black solid
interesting_facts: It exists in multiple allotropes, including highly reactive white phosphorus and more stable red phosphorus.
The name 'phosphorus' comes from Greek and means 'light-bringing', as white phosphorus glows in the dark.
It is an essential element for all life, found in DNA and cell membranes.

compounds.properties: A key ingredient in fertilizers, food additives (soda), and rust removal.
A powerful dehydrating agent used as a drying agent and in organic synthesis.

name: Sulfur
interesting_facts: It has a distinctive smell, often associated with volcanic activity or hot springs.
Sulfur is a crucial component of two amino acids, cysteine and methionine.
Pure sulfur is a bright yellow, crystalline solid.

compounds.properties: A strong mineral acid widely used in fertilizers, chemicals, and industrial processes.
A toxic gas with a characteristic rotten egg smell, often found in natural gas and volcanoes.

name: Chlorine
interesting_facts: It is a yellowish-green toxic gas in its elemental form.
Chlorine is a highly reactive halogen.
It is the 'Cl' in sodium chloride ($$NaCl$$), or table salt.

compounds.properties: Common table salt, an essential nutrient, and a preservative.
The active ingredient in household bleach, used for disinfection and whitening.

name: Argon
interesting_facts: It is a noble gas and is the third most abundant gas in the atmosphere.
Argon is used to create an inert environment to protect other materials from oxygen.
The name 'argon' comes from the Greek word for 'lazy' or 'inactive'.

compounds.properties: Argon is a noble gas and is extremely unreactive. It does not form stable compounds under normal conditions.

name: Potassium
interesting_facts: It is a highly reactive alkali metal that ignites on contact with water.
Potassium is an essential element for human nerve and muscle function.
It is found in many foods, including bananas and potatoes.

compounds.properties: Used as a salt substitute, in fertilizers, and in chemical manufacturing.
A strong base used in alkaline batteries and in the production of soft soaps.

name: Calcium
common_uses: Dietary supplement for strong bones and teeth
interesting_facts: It is an essential mineral for humans and animals, making up our bones and teeth.
Calcium is found in common rocks like limestone, marble, and chalk.
It is the fifth most abundant element in Earth's crust.

compounds.properties: The main component of limestone, marble, and chalk. Used in construction and as a dietary supplement.
Known as slaked lime, used in water treatment, mortar, and as a flocculant.

name: Magnesium
common_uses: Alloys for car parts and aircraft
interesting_facts: It is the lightest structural metal on the periodic table.
Magnesium burns with a brilliant white light.
It is a key component of chlorophyll, the substance that gives plants their green color.

compounds.properties: A white solid used in ceramics, as an antacid, and in refractory materials.
Known as Epsom salt, used in medicine, agriculture, and as a bath additive.

name: Aluminum
interesting_facts: It is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust.
Aluminum is highly recyclable and requires far less energy to recycle than to produce from ore.
It is naturally coated with a thin layer of protective oxide, which prevents corrosion.

compounds.properties: Found in nature as corundum (ruby, sapphire). Used in ceramics, abrasives, and as a catalyst support.
A component of antacids and a common flame retardant.

name: Scandium
common_uses: Sporting goods (e.g., bicycle frames, baseball bats)
interesting_facts: It is often used in alloys with aluminum to make them lighter and stronger.
Scandium is relatively rare and is not found as a free element in nature.
Its discovery was a key prediction of Dmitri Mendeleev's periodic table.

compounds.properties: Used in high-intensity lamps, lasers, and for a variety of specialty applications.

name: Titanium
interesting_facts: It is as strong as steel but about 45% lighter.
Titanium is highly resistant to corrosion and is biocompatible.
The name comes from the Titans of Greek mythology.

compounds.properties: A white pigment used in paints, sunscreen, and food coloring.
A colorless liquid used as an intermediate in the production of titanium metal and titanium dioxide.

name: Vanadium
interesting_facts: Its compounds exhibit a wide variety of beautiful colors.
The element is named after Vanadis, the Norse goddess of beauty and fertility.
It is a key element in the active site of some enzymes in living organisms.

compounds.properties: A catalyst used in the production of sulfuric acid and a colorant in ceramics.
Used in the development of high-performance vanadium redox flow batteries.

name: Chromium
common_uses: Chrome plating for durability and appearance
interesting_facts: The name comes from the Greek word 'chroma,' meaning 'color,' due to its colorful compounds.
Chromium is the element responsible for the red color of rubies and the green color of emeralds.
It can be toxic in its hexavalent form ($$CrO_{3}$$).

compounds.properties: Known as chrome green, a pigment used in paints, glass, and ceramics.
A powerful oxidizing agent used for chrome plating and in the production of other chromium chemicals.

name: Manganese
common_uses: Steel production (to improve hardness and strength)
interesting_facts: It is an essential trace mineral for all known living organisms.
Manganese is found in nodules on the ocean floor, which are a potential future source of the metal.
It is the main element in ferromanganese, a key component in steel production.

compounds.properties: Used in dry-cell batteries and as a black pigment in glazes and glass.
A strong oxidizing agent used in medicine and as a disinfectant.

name: Iron
appearance: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge
common_uses: Essential component of hemoglobin in blood
interesting_facts: Iron is the most common element on Earth by mass.
It is the primary component of Earth's core, both outer and inner.
Rusting is the process of iron oxidizing when exposed to moisture and air.

compounds.properties: Commonly known as rust. Used as a pigment in paints and for polishing glass.
Used to treat iron deficiency anemia and as a lawn conditioner to kill moss.

name: Cobalt
interesting_facts: The name 'cobalt' comes from the German word 'Kobold,' meaning 'goblin,' as miners believed a mischievous spirit was stealing other metals.
Cobalt-60 is a radioactive isotope used in medical radiation therapy.
It is an essential component of Vitamin B12.

compounds.properties: Used as a moisture indicator, as it changes color from blue (anhydrous) to pink (hydrated).
Used as a black pigment in ceramics and as a catalyst in various chemical processes.

name: Nickel
interesting_facts: Nickel is highly resistant to corrosion, which makes it perfect for use in coins and plating.
The name is a shortened form of 'kupfernickel,' or 'copper demon,' a German mining term.
It is the main element in the Earth's inner core, along with iron.

compounds.properties: A green powder used in ceramics, electronic components, and as a component of batteries.
Used as a starting material for the preparation of nickel-based catalysts.

name: Copper
interesting_facts: It was one of the first metals ever to be used by humans, starting around 8000 BCE.
Copper is a great conductor of electricity and heat.
It has natural antimicrobial properties, which prevent bacteria from growing on its surfaces.

compounds.properties: An inorganic compound used as a fungicide, algaecide, and herbicide.
A reddish powder used as a pigment, fungicide, and in antifouling paints for ships.

name: Zinc
interesting_facts: It is an essential mineral for humans and plants.
Zinc is a key component of the brass alloy.
Zinc oxide ($$ZnO$$) is used in sunscreens to block UV rays.

compounds.properties: A white powder used in sunscreens, cosmetics, and as a pigment.
Used as a fertilizer, a dietary supplement, and in medicine.

name: Gallium
interesting_facts: It has a melting point just above room temperature, so a solid piece of it can melt in your hand.
Gallium wets glass and ceramic surfaces, so it cannot be stored in them.
It was another element whose existence and properties were predicted by Dmitri Mendeleev.

compounds.properties: A semiconductor used in integrated circuits, LEDs, and solar panels.
A semiconductor with a high electron mobility, used in high-power electronics and blue LEDs.

name: Germanium
interesting_facts: It is a metalloid, meaning it has properties of both metals and nonmetals.
Germanium was used in early transistors, but it was largely replaced by silicon.
Its high transparency to infrared radiation makes it ideal for use in thermal imaging cameras.

compounds.properties: Used in the production of fiber optics and as a catalyst in PET plastic production.
A colorless liquid used as an intermediate in the production of high-purity germanium metal and its oxide.

name: Arsenic
appearance: metallic gray, steel gray, or tin-white
common_uses: Historically used in insecticides and rat poison
interesting_facts: Arsenic is a notorious poison, and its name is derived from the Greek word for 'yellow orpiment,' a mineral containing arsenic.
It can exist in several allotropes, including gray, black, and yellow forms.
In small, controlled doses, it has been used in some medical treatments.

compounds.properties: Used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia and historically as a pigment and rat poison.
A highly toxic gas used in the semiconductor industry as a doping agent.

name: Selenium
appearance: gray metallic (most stable form), also red and black amorphous forms
common_uses: Toner in photocopiers and laser printers
interesting_facts: Selenium's electrical conductivity increases when exposed to light, a property called photoconductivity.
It is an essential trace element for humans, but it is toxic in large amounts.
The name 'selenium' comes from the Greek word 'selene,' meaning 'moon,' as it was discovered alongside tellurium, named after Earth.

compounds.properties: A white solid used in glass and as an oxidizing agent in organic synthesis.
A colorless, flammable gas with a strong odor, highly toxic and used in the synthesis of other selenium compounds.

name: Bromine
interesting_facts: It is the only non-metallic element that is a liquid at room temperature.
Bromine has a very pungent, unpleasant odor, which is where its name comes from.
The name 'bromine' comes from the Greek word 'bromos', meaning 'stench'.

compounds.properties: A colorless gas used in the production of organic and inorganic bromides and as a catalyst in certain chemical reactions.
A white, crystalline solid used in photography and as a sedative in medicine.

name: Krypton
common_uses: Lighting products (e.g., fluorescent lamps, flash photography)
interesting_facts: It is a noble gas and is generally unreactive.
Krypton is named after the Greek word 'kryptos', meaning 'the hidden one', because of its low abundance.
It was once used to define the international standard for the meter.

compounds.properties: A highly reactive and unstable compound, it is a strong fluorinating agent and the only well-characterized compound of krypton.

name: Rubidium
interesting_facts: It is a highly reactive alkali metal that ignites spontaneously in air.
Rubidium must be stored under mineral oil to prevent it from reacting with the atmosphere.
The name comes from the Latin word 'rubidus', meaning 'deep red', for the color it emits in a flame test.

compounds.properties: A salt used in biochemical research as a biomarker and to induce DNA uptake in cells.
Used in the production of special glasses and ceramics.

name: Strontium
common_uses: Fireworks (to produce a bright red color)
Radioisotopes for medical use (Strontium-89 for bone cancer)
interesting_facts: It is named after a village in Scotland, Strontian, where the mineral strontianite was first found.
Strontium can be used to make glass for color television screens.
The radioactive isotope Strontium-90 is a byproduct of nuclear fission and a major health concern.

compounds.properties: Used to produce the brilliant red color in fireworks and flares, and in glass for cathode ray tube televisions.
A strong oxidizer that produces the characteristic red flame color of strontium.

name: Yttrium
common_uses: Phosphors for television and computer displays
Alloys to increase strength and corrosion resistance
interesting_facts: Yttrium is named after the Swedish village Ytterby, a source of many new minerals.
It is a key component in red phosphors used in old CRT television screens.
Yttrium-stabilized zirconia is used in dentistry for crowns and bridges.

compounds.properties: A white solid used in phosphors for red CRT phosphors and as a ceramic material.
A synthetic garnet with ferrimagnetic properties, used in microwave electronics and for various optical and magnetic applications.

name: Zirconium
interesting_facts: It is a highly corrosion-resistant metal, which is why it is used in nuclear reactors.
Zirconium is also found in cubic zirconia, a popular diamond simulant.
The name comes from the mineral zircon, a word of Arabic origin meaning 'golden color'.

compounds.properties: A white crystalline oxide used in ceramics, abrasives, and as a refractory material. It is also the main component of cubic zirconia.
The mineral zircon, a primary ore of zirconium, used in ceramics, foundry materials, and jewelry.

name: Niobium
interesting_facts: Niobium is named after Niobe, the daughter of the mythological Greek king Tantalus, because of its chemical similarity to tantalum.
At cryogenic temperatures, niobium becomes a superconductor, meaning it can conduct electricity with zero resistance.
The world's largest particle accelerators, like the Large Hadron Collider, use niobium-based superconducting magnets to steer particle beams.

compounds.properties: The most common form of niobium oxide, used in capacitors, optical lenses, and as a component in certain steel alloys.
A hard refractory ceramic material used in cutting tools and wear-resistant coatings.

name: Molybdenum
common_uses: Steel alloys (improves strength, hardness, and corrosion resistance)
Filaments for electric heaters and light bulbs
Lubricants in high-temperature applications (as molybdenum disulfide)
interesting_facts: Molybdenum is a crucial trace element for life and is found in enzymes that help with nitrogen fixation in bacteria.
Its name comes from the Greek word 'molybdos' meaning lead, as it was often confused with lead ore.
Molybdenum has one of the highest melting points of all pure elements.

compounds.properties: A black crystalline powder used as a solid lubricant in high-temperature and high-pressure environments.
A catalyst in the production of acrylonitrile and used as an important ingredient in steel alloys.

name: Technetium
interesting_facts: Technetium was the first element to be artificially produced in a lab, filling a gap in the periodic table.
Due to its radioactivity and short half-life, it's virtually nonexistent on Earth, aside from trace amounts in uranium ore.
The most stable isotope, Technetium-99, is a gamma-ray emitter, making it perfect for tracing in nuclear medicine to visualize organs like the heart, liver, and brain.

compounds.properties: A volatile, golden-yellow solid, it is the most common oxide of technetium and a precursor to other technetium compounds.
A dark-brown solid that is the main product of technetium metal oxidation.

name: Ruthenium
interesting_facts: Ruthenium is a rare and hard transition metal belonging to the platinum group.
It is an excellent hardener for palladium and platinum, and these alloys are used in electrical contacts.
Ruthenium can form a number of chemical compounds in a wide range of oxidation states, which is useful in chemical catalysis.

compounds.properties: A black solid with a wide range of applications, including as a catalyst and in electronics as a component of resistors.
A dark brown solid, it is an important precursor to other ruthenium compounds and a catalyst in organic synthesis.

name: Rhodium
interesting_facts: Rhodium is one of the rarest and most valuable precious metals, often costing more than gold and platinum.
It is a highly effective catalyst and is a key component in three-way catalytic converters, which reduce harmful emissions from vehicle exhaust.
The name comes from the Greek word 'rhodon' meaning rose, due to the color of its salt solutions.

compounds.properties: A red solid used as a starting material for the synthesis of many other rhodium compounds and as a catalyst.
A compound used as a catalyst in organic synthesis for its ability to form carbene intermediates.

name: Palladium
interesting_facts: Palladium has a unique ability to absorb up to 900 times its own volume of hydrogen at room temperature, making it a key element for hydrogen storage research.
It is one of the six platinum group metals (PGMs) and is less dense and has a lower melting point than the others.
Palladium is a popular substitute for platinum in jewelry due to its similar appearance and durability, as well as being a more affordable alternative.

compounds.properties: A common starting material for other palladium compounds and a precursor to catalysts used in organic chemistry.
An important catalyst used in many organic reactions, especially those involving cross-coupling reactions.

name: Silver
interesting_facts: Silver has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of all metals.
The name 'silver' comes from the Old English word 'seolfor'. Its chemical symbol, Ag, comes from the Latin word 'argentum'.
Silver has been used for centuries for its antimicrobial properties and is still used in medical applications and water purification.

compounds.properties: A colorless crystalline solid used in photography, as a precursor to other silver compounds, and as an antiseptic and cauterizing agent.
A yellow solid used in photography and as a cloud-seeding agent to produce rain.

name: Cadmium
common_uses: Pigments for plastics and ceramics (produces yellow, orange, and red colors)
interesting_facts: Cadmium is a toxic heavy metal, and its use is highly regulated in many countries.
It was discovered as an impurity in zinc carbonate and named after the Greek word 'kadmeia' for calamine, a zinc ore.
Cadmium's high neutron absorption cross-section makes it useful as a neutron absorber in nuclear power plants.

compounds.properties: A white crystalline solid used in electroplating, pigments, and fluorescent screens.
A yellow-orange pigment known as 'cadmium yellow,' used in paints and plastics. It is also a semiconductor used in photocells.

name: Indium
common_uses: Transparent electrodes for LCD screens and touchscreens (indium tin oxide)
Protective coatings for bearings in high-speed engines
interesting_facts: Indium is a very soft metal that can be scratched with a fingernail.
When bent, it makes a high-pitched 'cry' similar to tin, but for different metallurgical reasons.
It was named for the brilliant indigo blue line in its atomic emission spectrum.

compounds.properties: A mixture of indium oxide and tin oxide, known for being transparent and electrically conductive. It is the most widely used transparent conductor.
A semiconductor material used in high-power and high-frequency electronics, such as laser diodes and LEDs.

name: Tin
common_uses: Tin plating for steel cans (tin cans)
interesting_facts: Tin has the most stable isotopes of any element, with 10 of them being stable.
Tin is a soft, malleable, and low-melting-point metal. When a bar of tin is bent, a crackling sound known as 'tin cry' can be heard, which is caused by the deformation of its crystal structure.
Tin has been used by humans for thousands of years, most famously in the bronze age, where it was alloyed with copper to create bronze.

compounds.properties: A transparent oxide used in glazes for ceramics, a polishing powder for glass and steel, and in transparent electronic displays.
A white crystalline solid used as a reducing agent and as a mordant in dyeing textiles.

name: Antimony
common_uses: Alloys for batteries, bullets, and solders
interesting_facts: Antimony has been known since ancient times and was used as an eye cosmetic (kohl) in ancient Egypt.
The name 'antimony' is believed to come from the Greek words 'anti' and 'monos', meaning 'not alone', because it's rarely found as a pure element in nature.
It is a brittle metalloid that is a poor conductor of heat and electricity.

compounds.properties: A white powder used primarily as a flame retardant in plastics, rubber, and textiles.
A grayish-black compound found in the mineral stibnite. It is used in matches, fireworks, and as a pigment.

name: Tellurium
common_uses: Alloys to improve machinability (e.g., in steel and copper)
interesting_facts: Tellurium is one of the rarest solid elements in the Earth's crust, even rarer than gold or platinum.
It was named from the Latin word 'tellus' meaning 'earth'.
When exposed to air, tellurium produces a distinctive garlic-like odor that can linger on a person's breath and body for a long time.

compounds.properties: A semiconductor material used in thin-film solar cells, making them highly efficient.
A white, crystalline solid used in acousto-optic devices and as a component in glasses and ceramics.

name: Iodine
appearance: lustrous metallic gray, violet-black nonmetallic solid
common_uses: Medical imaging (iodine-131 for thyroid scans and treatments)
Food additive (iodized salt) to prevent goiter
interesting_facts: Iodine is a solid at room temperature and sublimes directly into a purple gas when heated.
The name comes from the Greek word 'iodes' meaning 'violet' or 'purple', referring to the color of its vapor.
Iodine is an essential nutrient for humans, particularly for the function of the thyroid gland.

compounds.properties: A white crystalline salt used to protect the thyroid gland from radioactive iodine and as a dietary supplement.

name: Xenon
common_uses: High-intensity lighting (xenon arc lamps for projectors and car headlights)
interesting_facts: Xenon is a noble gas, but unlike most of them, it can form compounds with highly electronegative elements like fluorine.
The name comes from the Greek word 'xenos' meaning 'stranger' or 'foreigner'.
Xenon is used in some of the most powerful lamps and is found in the flash tubes of high-speed cameras, producing a bright, white light.

compounds.properties: A powerful fluorinating agent used in chemical synthesis.
One of the first compounds of a noble gas to be synthesized, it is a stable, colorless solid.
The most reactive of the xenon fluorides, it is a colorless solid that forms a yellow vapor.
A highly explosive and powerful oxidizing agent that is a colorless solid.

name: Cesium
interesting_facts: Cesium is the most reactive of all the stable elements and will explode on contact with water or ice at any temperature above -116 °C.
It is one of only five metals that are liquid at or near room temperature.
The most accurate atomic clocks in the world are based on the vibration of cesium atoms, defining the second with extreme precision.

compounds.properties: A colorless crystalline solid used in molecular biology for density gradient centrifugation and as an optical component.
A source of fluoride ions in organic synthesis and a catalyst in some chemical reactions.
A colorless crystalline solid used as a pyrotechnic colorant to produce a bluish-violet flame.

name: Barium
common_uses: Barium sulfate as a radiocontrast agent for X-rays (barium meal)
Pyrotechnics (produces a green color in fireworks)
interesting_facts: Barium's name comes from the Greek word 'barys' meaning 'heavy', due to the high density of some of its ores.
Barium is a soft, reactive metal that is toxic to humans.
Despite its toxicity, a compound of barium, barium sulfate, is safe to ingest because it's insoluble and passes through the digestive system without being absorbed.

compounds.properties: An insoluble white solid used as a radiocontrast agent and a pigment. The low solubility makes it safe for ingestion.
A white solid used as a rodenticide, in ceramics, and to make other barium compounds. It is toxic.
A white hygroscopic solid used as a coating for cathode ray tubes and as a desiccant.

name: Lanthanum
common_uses: Camera and telescope lenses (lanthanum oxide improves glass's refractive index)
Mischmetal (a mixture of rare-earth metals) in lighter flints
Hybrid car batteries (as a component in nickel-metal hydride batteries)
interesting_facts: Lanthanum is the first element in the lanthanide series and is considered the prototype for the group.
Its name comes from the Greek word 'lanthanein', meaning 'to lie hidden', as it was difficult to separate from other rare-earth elements.
Lanthanum compounds can be used to treat kidney failure by lowering phosphate levels in the blood.

compounds.properties: Used in the production of high-quality optical glass, such as camera lenses, due to its high refractive index.
A precursor to other lanthanum compounds and a weak base used as a phosphate binder in medicine.

name: Cerium
common_uses: Polishing powders for glass and optics
Lighter flints (as part of a mischmetal alloy)
interesting_facts: Cerium is the most abundant of the rare-earth elements.
It was named after the dwarf planet Ceres, which was discovered around the same time as the element.
Cerium is a powerful reducing agent and can spontaneously ignite when scratched with a knife, especially in its powder form.

compounds.properties: A common polishing agent for glass and a component in automotive catalytic converters due to its oxidizing properties.
Used as a scintillating material in radiation detectors and in some carbon arc lamps.

name: Praseodymium
common_uses: Ceramics and glass (produces a yellow color)
interesting_facts: Praseodymium was discovered at the same time as neodymium and was named for the green color of its oxide salt.
The name comes from the Greek words 'prasios' meaning 'green' and 'didymos' meaning 'twin'.
Welding goggles often contain praseodymium to filter out the intense yellow light from the sodium in the flame.

compounds.properties: Used to color glass and ceramics a deep green or yellow and as a host for phosphors.
A water-soluble salt used as a source of the element in chemical reactions.

name: Neodymium
common_uses: Coloring glass and ceramics (produces violet to red-purple colors)
interesting_facts: Neodymium magnets are the strongest permanent magnets commercially available and are a critical component in electric motors, hard drives, and wind turbines.
The name is derived from the Greek words 'neos' and 'didymos', meaning 'new twin', because it was the 'new twin' to praseodymium, from which it was separated.
Neodymium-doped glass is used to create specific lasers and to produce pink-to-purple-colored glass.

compounds.properties: Used in the production of neodymium magnets and to create violet-colored glass.
Used in the production of neodymium metal by a reduction process.

name: Promethium
common_uses: Luminous paint (in older wristwatches and signs)
interesting_facts: Promethium is one of the two elements with an atomic number under 83 that has no stable isotopes, making it entirely radioactive.
Trace amounts of promethium exist in nature from the spontaneous fission of uranium-238 and other radioactive processes, but it is primarily synthesized in labs.
The element was named after the Greek titan Prometheus, who stole fire from the gods, symbolizing the human ability to create an element artificially.

compounds.properties: One of the few solid compounds of promethium that has been isolated and studied.
A water-soluble salt of promethium used in research.

name: Samarium
interesting_facts: Samarium-cobalt magnets are second only to neodymium magnets in strength and have a higher resistance to demagnetization at high temperatures.
The element was named after the mineral 'samarskite', in which it was first found. The mineral itself was named after a Russian mining engineer, Vasili Samarsky-Bykhovets.
Samarium has a high neutron absorption capacity, making it excellent for use in nuclear reactor control rods to regulate the nuclear fission rate.

compounds.properties: Used in the preparation of other samarium salts and for infrared absorbing glass.
A water-soluble salt used as a source of samarium ions in chemical research.
A permanent magnet with high resistance to demagnetization at elevated temperatures.

name: Europium
common_uses: Phosphors in television screens and fluorescent lamps (produces red and blue light)
interesting_facts: Europium is the most reactive of all the lanthanide metals and oxidizes quickly in air.
It was named after the continent of Europe.
Because of its light-emitting properties, europium is a crucial element in phosphors and is used to create the vibrant red and blue colors in CRT televisions and LED lighting.

compounds.properties: A red phosphor used in CRT televisions and fluorescent lamps to create the red color.
A compound with a stable +2 oxidation state, used in some chemical and electronic applications.

name: Gadolinium
interesting_facts: Gadolinium is highly magnetic at room temperature and is a crucial component in many MRI contrast agents, making internal organs and tissues more visible on scans.
It has one of the highest neutron-capture cross-sections of any element, making it extremely effective at absorbing neutrons.
The element was named after Johan Gadolin, a Finnish chemist, and the mineral 'gadolinite' in which it was discovered.

compounds.properties: Used as a control rod material in nuclear reactors due to its high neutron absorption capacity.
A water-soluble salt that serves as a precursor to other gadolinium compounds.

name: Terbium
common_uses: Green phosphors for TVs and fluorescent lamps
Solid-state devices (in some lasers and transducers)
interesting_facts: Terbium is known for its beautiful phosphorescence, emitting a bright green light when exposed to ultraviolet light.
Its name is derived from the village of Ytterby, Sweden, which is the source of many rare-earth elements.
Terbium's green phosphor properties are essential for creating the green color in CRT televisions and modern LED lighting.

compounds.properties: A common precursor for making other terbium compounds, notably a component of green phosphors.
A water-soluble salt used as a source of terbium ions in chemical reactions.

name: Dysprosium
interesting_facts: Dysprosium has a high thermal neutron absorption cross-section, making it valuable in nuclear applications.
The name comes from the Greek word 'dysprositos', meaning 'hard to get', because it was so difficult to isolate from other rare-earth elements.
Dysprosium is a critical component in the magnets used in electric vehicles and wind turbines, where it helps the magnets maintain their strength at higher temperatures.

compounds.properties: Used in ceramics, glass, and as a component in some types of lasers.
Used in the production of dysprosium metal.

name: Holmium
common_uses: Magnetic pole pieces (to create high magnetic fields)
Lasers for medical and dental use
interesting_facts: Holmium has the highest magnetic strength of any known element.
It was named after 'Holmia', the Latin name for Stockholm, Sweden, the native city of its discoverer.
Holmium-doped YAG lasers are used in medicine for procedures like breaking up kidney stones and treating glaucoma.

compounds.properties: Used as a colorant for glass, giving it a striking yellow or pink color depending on the light source.
A water-soluble salt used as a source of holmium ions in chemical research.

name: Erbium
common_uses: Photography and sunglasses (filters ultraviolet and infrared light)
Dyes for glass and ceramics (produces a pink color)
interesting_facts: Erbium is often used in optical amplifiers for fiber optic cables, where it strengthens light signals without having to convert them back to an electrical signal.
Like many other rare-earth elements, erbium was named after the village of Ytterby, Sweden.
Erbium-doped glass is used to make beautiful pink glass and crystal, and it is also used in sunglasses to absorb UV and infrared light.

compounds.properties: Used as a colorant for glass and porcelain, giving it a pink hue.
A water-soluble salt used as a source of the element in chemical reactions.

name: Thulium
interesting_facts: Thulium is the second rarest of the lanthanides, after promethium.
It was named after 'Thule', the ancient Greek name for a mythical country in the far north, believed to be Scandinavia.
Thulium-based lasers are used in medicine for delicate surgical procedures and are effective at cutting and coagulating tissue with minimal damage to surrounding areas.

compounds.properties: A common colorant for green-colored glass and a precursor to thulium metal.
A water-soluble salt used in chemical research and as a component in certain phosphors.

name: Ytterbium
interesting_facts: Ytterbium is named after the village of Ytterby, Sweden, where it was discovered.
It is a soft, malleable, and ductile element that is easily attacked by acids.
It can be used as a dopant in fiber optic cables and as a radiation source in portable X-ray machines.

compounds.properties: A common precursor for making other ytterbium compounds.
Used in fiber optic technology and some types of lasers.

name: Lutetium
interesting_facts: Lutetium is one of the most expensive and rare lanthanides.
Lutetium-177 is used in targeted radiation therapy for certain types of cancer.
It is the last element in the lanthanide series and is considered a rare-earth element.

compounds.properties: Used in high-refractive-index glass and as a host material for phosphors.
A water-soluble salt used in chemical research.

name: Hafnium
interesting_facts: Hafnium is very similar to zirconium and they are often found together in nature.
It has a very high neutron absorption cross-section, making it ideal for nuclear reactor control rods.
Hafnium oxide is used as a high-k dielectric in modern microprocessors.

compounds.properties: Used as a high-k dielectric in modern semiconductor manufacturing.
An important precursor to hafnium metal and other hafnium compounds.

name: Tantalum
common_uses: Capacitors for mobile phones and electronics
interesting_facts: Tantalum is highly resistant to corrosion due to the formation of a protective oxide layer.
The name 'Tantalum' comes from the Greek mythological figure Tantalus, due to the difficulty in dissolving it in acid.
It is a key material in the electronics industry for creating small, high-capacity capacitors.

compounds.properties: A white solid used in the production of electronic components, such as capacitors and high-refractive-index glass.
An extremely hard, refractory ceramic material used in cutting tools and wear-resistant coatings.

name: Tungsten
interesting_facts: Tungsten has the highest melting point and the lowest vapor pressure of all metals.
Its name comes from the Swedish words 'tung sten' meaning 'heavy stone'.
It is an essential element in the production of hard materials like tungsten carbide.

compounds.properties: A very hard material, often mixed with other metals to create cutting tools, armor-piercing ammunition, and wear-resistant surfaces.
A yellow powder used in producing tungstates for fireproofing fabrics and in gas sensors.

name: Rhenium
interesting_facts: Rhenium is one of the rarest elements in the Earth's crust.
It has one of the highest melting points of all elements, second only to tungsten.
Rhenium alloys are used to create the hottest components of jet engines, such as turbine blades.

compounds.properties: A yellowish solid that is the starting material for many other rhenium compounds and a catalyst in organic synthesis.
A compound used as a precursor for other rhenium compounds and as a mild oxidizing agent.

name: Osmium
interesting_facts: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element.
It is incredibly hard and brittle, making it difficult to work with.
The name 'Osmium' comes from the Greek word 'osme' meaning 'smell', due to the pungent odor of its volatile oxide.

compounds.properties: A highly toxic, volatile solid with a characteristic pungent smell. It is a powerful oxidizing agent used to stain biological samples for microscopy.

name: Iridium
interesting_facts: Iridium is the most corrosion-resistant metal known.
It is found in meteorites and is considered a key indicator of asteroid impacts.
Iridium is named after Iris, the Greek goddess of the rainbow, because its salts are highly colored.

compounds.properties: A blue-black solid used as a pigment and as a catalyst in various chemical reactions.
A compound used as a precursor for the synthesis of other iridium-containing catalysts.

name: Platinum
interesting_facts: Platinum is a noble metal, meaning it resists corrosion and oxidation.
It is much rarer than gold.
The name 'Platinum' comes from the Spanish 'platina', meaning 'little silver'.

compounds.properties: A widely used chemotherapy drug for treating various cancers.
A commercially important platinum compound, used as a precursor for other platinum compounds and as a catalyst.

name: Gold
interesting_facts: Gold is a highly malleable and ductile metal, with a single ounce able to be hammered into a 300 square foot sheet.
It is a noble metal and does not corrode or tarnish.
All the gold ever mined would fit into a cube about 22 meters on a side.

compounds.properties: A common gold compound used in the synthesis of other gold complexes and as a catalyst in organic chemistry.

name: Mercury
interesting_facts: Mercury is the only metal that is a liquid at standard temperature and pressure.
It is highly toxic and its use has been restricted in many applications.
The Roman god Mercury, known for his speed, is the namesake for the element due to its fluid nature.

compounds.properties: A white powder that was once used as a purgative and is now primarily used in reference electrodes in electrochemistry.
An organic mercury compound that is a potent neurotoxin and bioaccumulates in aquatic food chains.

name: Thallium
common_uses: Historic use as a rodenticide and insecticide
interesting_facts: Thallium is a soft, malleable metal that tarnishes to a bluish-gray color.
It is extremely toxic and was once known as the 'poisoner's poison'.
The name 'Thallium' comes from the Greek 'thallos', meaning 'green twig', because of the bright green line in its spectrum.

compounds.properties: A highly toxic, odorless, and tasteless compound once used as a potent rodent and ant poison.

name: Lead
interesting_facts: Lead has been used for thousands of years, with the Romans using it for water pipes.
It is a heavy, soft, and malleable metal with a low melting point.
The use of lead in paint and gasoline has been phased out due to its toxicity, particularly to children.

compounds.properties: A yellow or red crystalline compound used in the production of lead glass, ceramics, and some batteries.
A colorless crystalline solid used as a heat stabilizer in nylon and polyester, and in some explosive mixtures.

name: Bismuth
appearance: lustrous, crystalline, brittle, white metal with a pinkish tinge
common_uses: Bismuth alloys for fire detection systems and solders
Pharmaceuticals, especially for treating stomach ailments
interesting_facts: Bismuth was long confused with tin and lead.
It is the most diamagnetic metal, meaning it is strongly repelled by a magnetic field.
Bismuth has a very low melting point and is known for forming beautiful, iridescent crystals when cooled slowly.

compounds.properties: A compound used in over-the-counter medications to treat indigestion, heartburn, and diarrhea.
A yellow powder used in the manufacture of fireproofing materials, catalysts, and glasses.

name: Polonium
common_uses: Alpha particle source for research and static eliminators
interesting_facts: Polonium was the first element discovered by Marie and Pierre Curie.
Marie Curie named it after her native country, Poland.
It is an extremely radioactive and toxic element, with Polonium-210 being a key component in certain nuclear weapons.

compounds.properties: The most stable oxide of polonium, produced by the oxidation of polonium with oxygen.

name: Astatine
common_uses: Medical applications, specifically in targeted alpha-particle therapy (TAT) for cancer
interesting_facts: Astatine is the rarest naturally occurring element in the Earth's crust.
Its name comes from the Greek word 'astatos', meaning 'unstable'.
Only a few grams of astatine have ever been produced, and its properties are mostly theoretical.

compounds.properties: A very unstable and highly acidic compound, but its properties are largely extrapolated from the other hydrogen halides.

name: Radon
appearance: colorless gas, glows red in a discharge tube
interesting_facts: Radon is a colorless, odorless, and tasteless radioactive gas.
It is a significant health hazard, as it can accumulate in buildings and cause lung cancer.
Radon is produced from the decay of uranium and thorium in rocks and soil.

compounds.properties: The only known compound of radon, but it is highly unstable and has not been isolated in bulk.

name: Francium
common_uses: No practical uses due to its extreme rarity and instability
interesting_facts: Francium is the second-rarest element in the Earth's crust after astatine.
It is the least electronegative element and the heaviest alkali metal.
The longest-lived isotope has a half-life of only 22 minutes, so it is difficult to study its properties.

compounds.properties: A theoretical compound, expected to behave similarly to other alkali metal chlorides but its properties are inferred due to the extreme instability of francium.

name: Radium
common_uses: Historically used in luminous paints for watches and dials
Source of radon gas for research
interesting_facts: Radium is a highly radioactive element that glows faintly in the dark.
It was once thought to have health benefits and was added to products like tonics and toothpaste.
The name 'Radium' comes from the Latin word 'radius', meaning 'ray', due to its radioactivity.

compounds.properties: A salt of radium, used by Marie Curie to isolate the element from uranium ore.
A very insoluble compound of radium, which precipitates when radium is in solution with sulfates.

name: Actinium
common_uses: As a neutron source for research
interesting_facts: Actinium is approximately 150 times more radioactive than radium.
Its name comes from the Greek word 'aktis', meaning 'ray' or 'beam', because of its radioactivity.
It is one of the first elements in the actinide series, which gives its name to the entire group.

compounds.properties: The only known oxide of actinium, a white solid that is isotypic with the oxides of most trivalent rare-earth metals.

name: Thorium
common_uses: Nuclear fuel in some reactor designs
interesting_facts: Thorium is a radioactive element, but its most common isotope has a very long half-life, making it less dangerous than some others.
It is named after Thor, the Norse god of thunder.
Thorium is a promising alternative to uranium for nuclear power generation due to its abundance and lower waste production.

compounds.properties: A refractory oxide with a very high melting point, historically used in gas lantern mantles and as a component of special ceramics.
A white crystalline salt, a primary intermediate in the production of thorium compounds.

name: Protactinium
common_uses: No practical uses due to its rarity and radioactivity
interesting_facts: Protactinium is one of the rarest and most expensive naturally occurring elements.
Its name means 'before actinium' because it decays into actinium.
It is a highly toxic and radioactive element.

compounds.properties: A white solid and the most stable oxide of protactinium, used as a starting material for other protactinium compounds.
A compound used in the purification of protactinium from uranium ore.

name: Uranium
interesting_facts: Uranium is the heaviest naturally occurring element.
It is named after the planet Uranus, which had been discovered just before the element.
Uranium-235 is the only naturally occurring fissile isotope, meaning it can sustain a nuclear chain reaction.

compounds.properties: A volatile solid used in the gas centrifuge process to enrich uranium for use in nuclear power plants and weapons.
A black solid used as a nuclear fuel in light water reactors.

name: Neptunium
interesting_facts: Neptunium was the first synthetic transuranic element to be discovered.
It is named after the planet Neptune, which is the next planet after Uranus.
Neptunium is highly radioactive and its most stable isotope has a half-life of over 2 million years.

compounds.properties: A solid oxide of neptunium, which is the most common and stable form of neptunium compounds.

name: Plutonium
discoveredBy: Glenn T. Seaborg, Edwin M. McMillan, Joseph W. Kennedy, Arthur C. Wahl (1940)
common_uses: Power source for spacecraft and pacemakers
interesting_facts: Plutonium is named after the dwarf planet Pluto, the next celestial body after Neptune.
It is a highly toxic and radioactive element, and its dust can be inhaled and cause cancer.
Plutonium-238 is used in radioisotope thermoelectric generators (RTGs) to power spacecraft like Voyager and Cassini.

compounds.properties: A ceramic compound used as a nuclear fuel, often in a mix with uranium dioxide.
A highly volatile and corrosive solid used in the processing of plutonium from spent nuclear fuel.

name: Americium
discoveredBy: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso (1944)
common_uses: Portable gamma ray sources for medical diagnostics
interesting_facts: Americium is named after the Americas.
Americium-241 is the most common isotope and is used in household smoke detectors.
It is a highly radioactive element and must be handled with extreme care.

compounds.properties: The most stable oxide of americium, a brown-black solid.

name: Curium
discoveredBy: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso (1944)
common_uses: Research applications, primarily as a source of alpha particles
interesting_facts: Curium is named after the scientists Marie and Pierre Curie.
It is a highly radioactive, silvery-white metal that glows in the dark.
Curium-248 is a potential fuel for fusion-fission hybrid reactors.

compounds.properties: A white solid and the most stable oxide of curium.

name: Berkelium
discoveredBy: Stanley G. Thompson, Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg (1949)
common_uses: Research applications, specifically in the synthesis of new elements
interesting_facts: Berkelium is named after the city of Berkeley, California, where it was first synthesized at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.
It is a highly radioactive element, with no known practical applications outside of scientific research.
Berkelium-249 was used as the target material to create tennessine, element 117.

compounds.properties: A brownish-red solid, which is one of the few berkelium compounds that have been synthesized.

name: Californium
discoveredBy: Stanley G. Thompson, Kenneth Street Jr., Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg (1950)
common_uses: Neutron source for nuclear reactors and cancer treatment
Analysis of materials for metal fatigue
interesting_facts: Californium is named after the state and the University of California, Berkeley.
Californium-252 is an extremely powerful neutron emitter and is used in a wide range of applications, from starting nuclear reactors to treating certain types of cancer.
It is a highly radioactive element and is produced in very small quantities.

compounds.properties: A compound that has been prepared in microgram quantities and studied to determine the chemical properties of californium.

name: Einsteinium
interesting_facts: Einsteinium was discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb test.
It is named in honor of Albert Einstein.
Only microscopic amounts of einsteinium have been produced, and its properties are not well-known.

compounds.properties: A very small amount of this compound was synthesized in 1970 to study the chemical properties of the element.

name: Fermium
interesting_facts: Fermium was also discovered in the debris of the first hydrogen bomb test.
It is named after the physicist Enrico Fermi, who developed the first nuclear reactor.
It is the last element that can be created by neutron bombardment, and it is the heaviest element that can be produced in macroscopic amounts.

compounds.properties: Fermium compounds have not been isolated, but its ions have been studied in solution, showing it can exist in both a +2 and +3 oxidation state.

name: Mendelevium
discoveredBy: Albert Ghiorso, Glenn T. Seaborg, Bernard G. Harvey, Gregory R. Choppin, Stanley G. Thompson (1955)
interesting_facts: Mendelevium was named after Dmitri Mendeleev, the creator of the periodic table.
It was the first element to be synthesized one atom at a time.
Its discovery helped to confirm the location of the actinide series in the periodic table.

compounds.properties: The chemical properties of mendelevium have been studied in solution, with the +2 oxidation state being a characteristic feature of this element.

name: Nobelium
discoveredBy: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (1966), University of California, Berkeley (1966)
interesting_facts: Nobelium is named in honor of Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite and founder of the Nobel Prizes.
Its discovery was disputed for a time, with both American and Russian scientists claiming credit.
It is a highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.

compounds.properties: Similar to mendelevium, nobelium compounds have not been isolated, but its ions have been studied in solution, showing a very stable +2 oxidation state.

name: Lawrencium
discoveredBy: Albert Ghiorso, Torbjørn Sikkeland, Almon E. Larsh, Robert M. Latimer (1961)
interesting_facts: Lawrencium is the last element of the actinide series.
It is named after Ernest O. Lawrence, the inventor of the cyclotron.
It is a highly radioactive and unstable element, with its properties being inferred from its position in the periodic table.

compounds.properties: Due to its very short half-life, only the aqueous chemistry of lawrencium has been investigated, confirming a stable +3 oxidation state.

name: Rutherfordium
discoveredBy: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (1964), University of California, Berkeley (1969)
interesting_facts: Rutherfordium is the first transactinide element and is named after Ernest Rutherford.
Its discovery was also a source of controversy between American and Russian scientists.
It is a very heavy, synthetic, and highly radioactive element, with its longest-lived isotope having a half-life of only a few hours.

compounds.properties: The chemical properties of rutherfordium were studied by forming a volatile tetrachloride compound, which confirmed its placement in group 4 of the periodic table.

name: Dubnium
discoveredBy: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (1968), University of California, Berkeley (1970)
interesting_facts: Dubnium is named after the Russian city of Dubna, where the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research is located.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with no practical applications.
Its chemical properties are thought to be similar to those of its lighter homolog, tantalum.

compounds.properties: Experimental studies have shown that dubnium forms a volatile pentachloride, confirming its position in group 5.

name: Seaborgium
discoveredBy: Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory (1974), Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (1974)
interesting_facts: Seaborgium is named after the American chemist Glenn T. Seaborg, who was involved in the discovery of many transuranic elements.
It was the first element named after a living person.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.

compounds.properties: A very volatile carbonyl compound that has been used in gas-phase chemistry experiments to study the chemical properties of seaborgium, which are similar to tungsten.

name: Bohrium
interesting_facts: Bohrium is named after the Danish physicist Niels Bohr.
Its discovery helped to confirm the periodic law for very heavy elements.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.

compounds.properties: A compound that has been synthesized and used in experiments to confirm that bohrium behaves as a group 7 element, similar to rhenium.

name: Hassium
interesting_facts: Hassium is named after the German state of Hesse, where its discovery was made.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.
Hassium is predicted to be a dense and noble metal, similar to osmium.

compounds.properties: A volatile tetroxide compound that has been studied to determine the chemical properties of hassium, confirming its position as a group 8 element like osmium.

name: Meitnerium
interesting_facts: Meitnerium is named after the physicist Lise Meitner, who contributed to the discovery of nuclear fission.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.
The element's properties are mostly theoretical due to the small number of atoms that have been produced.

compounds.compound: Meitnerium has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: Due to its extremely short half-life and the very small number of atoms ever synthesized, no compounds of meitnerium have been created or studied.

name: Darmstadtium
interesting_facts: Darmstadtium is named after the city of Darmstadt, Germany, where the GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research is located.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.
It is expected to be a solid metal at room temperature.

compounds.compound: Darmstadtium has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: Similar to meitnerium, darmstadtium is too unstable and has been produced in such small quantities that no chemical compounds have been synthesized or studied.

name: Roentgenium
interesting_facts: Roentgenium is named after Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, who discovered X-rays.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.
Its properties are expected to be similar to those of gold, but it is too unstable to be studied in bulk.

compounds.compound: Roentgenium has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: Due to its extremely short half-life and the small number of atoms produced, no compounds of roentgenium have been synthesized or studied.

name: Copernicium
interesting_facts: Copernicium is named after the astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.
It is predicted to be a volatile metal, possibly a liquid at room temperature.

compounds.compound: Copernicium has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: Given its extreme instability, chemical studies of copernicium have been limited to a few atoms, and no compounds have been successfully formed.

name: Nihonium
interesting_facts: Nihonium is named after the Japanese word for Japan, 'Nihon'.
It was the first element to be discovered in an Asian country.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.

compounds.compound: Nihonium has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: Due to its very short half-life, no compounds of nihonium have been created. Its chemical properties are predicted to be similar to thallium but its behavior is unknown.

name: Flerovium
interesting_facts: Flerovium is named after the Russian physicist Georgi Flyorov, who founded the JINR.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.
It is predicted to be a volatile metal with properties similar to lead.

compounds.compound: Flerovium has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: The chemical properties of flerovium have been studied on a few atoms at a time, suggesting it is a noble metal with weak interactions, similar to a noble gas. No stable compounds have been formed.

name: Moscovium
interesting_facts: Moscovium is named after the Moscow Oblast region of Russia.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.
Only a few atoms of moscovium have ever been synthesized.

compounds.compound: Moscovium has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: The half-life of moscovium is so short that it is highly unlikely any compounds could be formed or studied.

name: Livermorium
interesting_facts: Livermorium is named after the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element with a very short half-life.
Its properties are expected to be similar to those of polonium.

compounds.compound: Livermorium has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: The half-life of livermorium is too short to allow for the study or synthesis of its compounds.

name: Tennessine
discoveredBy: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR), Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), Vanderbilt University, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) (2010)
interesting_facts: Tennessine is named after the state of Tennessee, home to ORNL and Vanderbilt University.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element and is the second-heaviest element ever created.
It is predicted to be a solid at room temperature and is the only halogen in its period.

compounds.compound: Tennessine has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: Due to its extremely short half-life, no compounds of tennessine have been synthesized or studied. Its chemical properties are only theoretical.

name: Oganesson
interesting_facts: Oganesson is named after the nuclear physicist Yuri Oganessian.
It is the heaviest element in the periodic table.
It is a synthetic, highly radioactive element and its properties are largely unknown due to its short half-life and small quantity.

compounds.compound: Oganesson has no known stable compounds.
compounds.properties: With a half-life of less than a millisecond, oganesson is too unstable to form chemical bonds, and no compounds have been synthesized.
